Saturday, January 17, 2009

S is for...

Here's the latest installment for our letter of the week, along with a few extra words that make their initial S sound.
Sesame seeds
The word sesame seeds comes from the Latin word semisamae meaning sesamum indicum.
Sesame seed is the world’s oldest condiment. Sesame has been cultivated for over 4000 years. It is first mentioned in early Egyptian hieroglyphics. The Chinese referred to sesame seeds as "oil that never grows stale."
Sesame seeds grow in pods that resemble beans. When the seed pod begins to mature it pops open to reveal the sesame seeds.
The tiny sesame seed is extremely nutritious. It contains protein, oil, calcium, potassium, phosphorus, iron, thiamine, riboflavin and fiber.
The two most common varities of sesame seeds are the brown and white sesame seed. However, they are also produced in black, tan, and yellow. In Asia, sesame seeds are used in foods. In Africa, sesame seeds are used as a coffee substitute.
The seed of the white sesame is usually larger and plumper than the dark seed.
In Asia, sesame seeds are an important ingredient in stir-fry dishes, soups, and desserts. Black sesame seeds are popular in Japan and China.
Sesame seeds are also used to flavor various meats, breads, and pastries. White sesame seeds are most often used in baked goods. In China, sesame seeds are used in sweet pastries, cakes, and cookies. In the Mediterranean region, sesame seeds are used to flavor pastas, breads, and salads.
Sesame oil is made from sesame seeds. Sesame oil is used to flavor food, as a salad dressing, and to massage achy muscles. It is considered to be a "healthy oil." It contains linoleic acid, magnesium, iron, zinc, phosphorus, vitamin E and fiber. Sesame oil is available in liquid form or semi-solid form.
The world's longest word is a word that begins with a string of 17 Sesame seeds. That word is sesquipedalian which means "a big word" which is probably not surprising.

Can a poem be written in a haiku form?

It's possible for a poem to be written as a haiku, but most of the time that haiku will not be a haiku, strictly speaking. A haiku is a form of poetry in which the poet attempts to capture a certain mood or feeling by describing a scene. The scene is very important because it helps to establish the mood, but it's not the only thing that goes into a haiku.

In fact, many poems that are considered haikus are not haikus at all. For example, the following poem was written by a poet named George Eliot:

A haiku consists of three lines, each of which should be less than ten syllables long.

Write a haiku: I like the Haiku poems a lot. They’re short, but the poem tells us much more than it seems. There are a few rules though:

* There are only three lines
* The first line has five syllables
* The second line has seven syllables
* The third line has five syllables

Here is a nice haiku example from my wife:

The first snow
Falls gently on my window pane,
Peace is near

Write a ballad: Ballads usually tell a story. There are quite a few rules for ballads as well. Here are the main elements of a ballad:

* They are usually about love
* The mood is dramatic
* It has to have a specific rhythm and number of syllables
* Every verse has to rhyme
* It has a refrains

Here is a nice example of a ballad:

Roses are red,
Violets are blue,
Sugar is sweet,
And so are you!

Write a diamonte poem: The daimonte poem is a diamond-shaped poem. I have never used this before, so I had to search for more examples:

Joy –
Cheerful, content
Happiness and laughter

Calm –
Soft, peaceful
Gentle, calm
Quiet, serene

Write a concrete poem: Concrete poems are poems that use a type of text formatting to reflect the subject of the poem. A concrete poem can also be described as a shaped poem. You can read more about the concrete poem on

Write a diamante poem: The diamante poem is a poem that has a very specific form. The example poems can be found in the link.

Write a couplet: The couplet is a type of poem where two lines rhyme. The rhyme scheme is a, a and every line is similar in rhythm. There are actually two different types of couplets:

* Heroic couplets: A pair of lines in poetry that together form a complete idea or thought.
* Distich: Two lines of verse forming a complete thought or unit of meaning.

Here is a nice example of a couplet:

My love for you is so deep and true
I never want to lose our love.

Write a cinquain: A cinquain is a poem with five lines. This is a popular poetry exercise for kids as well. I have written a few cinquains myself:

Proud bird, flying high,
You always sing a song
About spring

Is la an interjection?

LA Interjection – La is used as an interjection to express exasperation, dismay, or disapproval.

What does it mean when a girl says la?

“La” means “I do not care”. If a girl does not care about you, it usually means that she is not attracted to you. … A girl says “La” when she doesn’t want to talk to you anymore. This usually means she is not interested in you.

How do you use La in a sentence?

We use “la” as an article to refer to feminine singular nouns. It is followed by a noun. We also use “la” to refer to feminine singular adjectives, which are often followed by an object. In Spanish, we use “la” before masculine singular and feminine singular nouns that start with a vowel.

Spanish masculine and feminine words

In Spanish, we use la when we are referring to something or someone that is feminine, and los when referring to a group of things that are masculine. The plural of the article la is las.

Write a haiku: 
A haiku must follow this format: 
a 5 syllable line 
a 7 syllable line 
a 5 syllable line
This haiku follows these rules.

Haikus can be about absolutely anything. This haiku is about me, because I'm a poet and I write about poetry, among other things. If you need help writing a poem or a haiku specifically, don't be afraid to ask. It may be hard to tell at first, but writing poems, as well as writing other kinds of essays, can be pretty easy. If you know what you're doing, that is. You'll want to be able to do some editing, and if you are working on something, you will want to know if it is good or bad.

I write poetry because I like to write, and I like to write poetry, and I also like to read what other people write, just as long as it is good poetry. I don't really read haikus that often, mostly because I don't really know all of the rules or really anything of the rules of haiku writing. Most of the time when I write poetry, I try to fit in all of the things that I want to say, and usually that means that I can't write everything that I want to, or everything that I think is important about what I am trying to say. I just like to write things down. I like writing about stuff that I care about, because if I cared about it enough to write about it, I don't really care that much that someone else will read it. It would be nice if it were read, but that would just be a bonus for me. I write poetry mostly to express myself, and to get other people to understand the things that I am trying to express, and what I am trying to express to others through poetry is pretty simple: what I like and what I don't like about the world.

Sometimes I like to think about the world as a whole, like, if I was given the choice between not knowing what is in the universe and only knowing about what exists on Earth, I would probably want to know the universe. I don't like knowing everything. I don't think it is possible for me, or anyone else, to know everything, so I would rather know about everything. I like being aware of how much there is in the universe, and I know that there is a lot, because I can

Write a haiku: It's a great way to get more creative with your kids. Try writing a haiku together and then have your child add a drawing and share in the comments. We'd love to see what you make!

Play a board game: This can be a quick or involved activity to do with your child depending on the game. Some great suggestions include UNO, Sorry!, Checkers, and Chutes and Ladders.

Learn a new skill: The most fun way to learn a new skill is to try and teach it to someone else. When I was learning how to make bread last year, I got to teach my daughter how to make bread too! It was a really great way to bond as a family and feel the success of creating something from scratch.

Cook something together: One of the best family traditions we have is baking cookies with our daughters. We do this as a team and it is such a fun way to bond with our girls! Have your child help you prep ingredients and even create the end product! Whether it is a quick cookie or a more complex dish, it's a great way to spend time with your children.

Draw or paint together: Drawing or painting a picture together with your kids is a great way to spend time together and bond. Plus you get to show them that everyone is creative in their own way. You don't need to create a masterpiece; just make something fun and something that you can do together.

Play a sport together: Playing a sport with your kids can be a great way to bond. You can teach your child how to play a new game or you can compete against each other. Even if you don't win, you will have a great time together!

Ride a bike with your kids: It can be a little tricky getting your kids on a bike, but if they are old enough, it can be a great family activity. Riding a bike with your kids is a great way to bond and get some exercise at the same time.

These are just a few of our suggestions for fun ways to spend time with your kids this summer. We hope that you have a great time and make some amazing memories!

Tips for Bonding With Your Child While Working From Home

There are plenty of ways to bond with your child while working from home.

Write a haiku: 2 lines of 5 syllables each and one line of 7 syllables. This could be a way to record all that you have learned on the trail.

Activity for each day: Take a minute to write about what you did during the day and how it went. What kind of things did you eat? What kind of bugs did you have to deal with? If you are going camping or backpacking, what are your plans for the weekend? What is there to do? Did your plans change? If you are on a bike ride, where are you going and how do you plan to get there? Where did you stop and how long did you stop? Did you see any interesting animals? Did you have to deal with any rain or snow or other inclement weather? If you are going with a group, were you tired at the end of the day? Did you miss your family? Did you sleep well?

Activity to do at the end of your outing: It can be fun to write about your favorite part of the outing and how you felt at the end. Take a few minutes and write about what you would tell people you wish you could tell them about. You might think of this as a letter that you never sent.

Journaling in the Backcountry

In the backcountry, you need to be more careful in how you dispose of waste. When you are in a camping area or campground you can usually use a garbage can, but in the wilderness, you can be responsible for disposing of your waste and protecting the wildlife. Many places have designated latrines or toilets that need to be used. They are usually a little ways away from the campsite. If you are in a place that does not have a proper facility for toilet use, you should choose an area where you can bury human waste to reduce the possibility of disease. In many places in the country, it is illegal to bury human waste on national lands. It is important that you follow all guidelines as to the disposal of waste.

Write a haiku: the sea’s salty water
stains her cheek with a briny smile; she floats and floats.

Write a story:  Ariel was born under the waves in the middle of the ocean, far away from land. Her mother and father had no idea of life above the water and neither did Ariel. As she swam with the fishes and the turtles, she often imagined what it must feel like to be above the waves, but she was too afraid to try it. So, one day, her dad took her on a little adventure.

It was a bright and sunny day and the water was calm and the sea air was light and salty on her face, she enjoyed the beauty of the underwater world. She saw tiny plankton floating by, sea turtles munching on the grass of the ocean floor, colorful fish, and even a sea turtle with the biggest shell she had ever seen!

But her father was an adventurous sea turtle and he encouraged Ariel to go further out from the shore. She had never been this far out before and she didn’t want to go any further. But she didn’t want to disappoint her father either.

“Come on, daughter, you can do it. You are almost there and I promise if you don’t like it we can go back,” he told her.

So she took a big breath and swam and swam and swam until finally she saw land. It was beautiful! There were trees and flowers and houses and lights and people and noise. She wasn’t sure what to do first. And then she saw a boy.

He was cute! And he had beautiful blue eyes. He was looking for his dog, his parents said he was 8 years old. But then he jumped in the water and swam toward her! She couldn’t believe it! A person swimming in the water!

He reached her and smiled and said “Hi” and that was it. She was in love!

Ariel’s father didn’t want to interrupt, but he wanted to tell Ariel that she has just discovered that she was not the only one who lived in the ocean. But he thought it would be best to leave that for another time. They swam back to the shore where Ariel got to meet the boy’s family.

And the rest of her life was happy and exciting. But she never forgot her father who encouraged her to go above the waves. But she also never forgot her mother, who stayed under the waves with her dad.

Write a haiku: what about a little light in the fridge
A little light in the fridge

What about this: a little light in the fridge
a little light in the fridge
the fridge is dark

You can do better than that.

The poem was originally written like this:

In the fridge
a little light
the fridge is dark


Haiku is all about the juxtaposition of seemingly disparate things to create something new; it has very little to do with what actually happens to be in your fridge. Let’s take a look at this haiku from the same anthology:

Lily of the valley
the white petals of her gown,
the white tomb

This poem does a great job juxtaposing an object of great joy with one of great sadness: love and death are in the same frame as the white petals of the lily of the valley and her white burial gown. That’s the magic of a haiku.

Okay, one more thing. While we are talking about haiku and syllables, it is important to remember that syllables don’t always map one-to-one between languages. The Japanese language is not based on the same phonetic principles as English, so the syllable counts for this haiku and the previous one do not necessarily correlate.

Let’s look at another haiku that I found in the same volume:

The cat’s eyes open
as if she were about to say
something important.

The English syllable count for this haiku is 4, 7, 4. The Japanese language does not divide sounds in quite the same way, so this haiku is often written in what we would call the 5, 7, 5 form. This is what the poem would look like in Japanese:

Neko no me ni
Adeyaku hajimeru yo
Ki no oto

If you read Japanese (which I don’t) and want to try writing haiku in that language, here are a few more resources:

You can also check out the Japanese page on Wikipedia.

Finally, here’s a haiku for you:

What if we wrote
a haiku contest
for our haiku contest?

You write the contest haiku in the comment section.

Write a haiku: 2.5 minutes

Take a moment to read about what Haiku poetry is and where it comes from. Then pick any subject or object you see and try to write your own haiku. 

Write a story: 2.5 minutes

Write a 100 word story about anything you like. It can be as complicated and detailed as you like, or as simple as possible!

Get creative with words

This exercise will encourage you to think of words in new, creative ways.  

Take a random word and think of all the other words or phrases you can think of related to that word. The words can be linked to the word by:

  • describing the word, like “the word is yellow”
  • using the word in a phrase, like “the word is a person”
  • rhyming, like “the word is a bird”

Do this with a selection of different words and see if you can think of lots of words and phrases related to each word.

Take a word from the words you’ve created and create some poetry or a story or essay around that word.

Remember – the sky is the limit!

Last reviewed: 26 Apr 2020

Write a haiku: sun, moon, stars
It’s the longest night of the year, and we are entering the darkness
Of Winter Solstice.

It’s also a time of darkness, or the darkness of winter solstice where the days are short and the nights are long. In these days, we are reminded of the importance of community and family and the light of love that keeps us warm and bright. In these winter days, we are reminded to keep our lights shining. full_output: Write a haiku:

Write a haiku: a haiku is a poem that describes something in nature. In a haiku, you use sensory details to describe what you’re seeing. In a haiku, there are no rhymes or meter and the poem is made up of three lines.

Here’s an example of a haiku poem:

“Snowy day

Walking through the park

Softly falling flakes”

Here are some more poems about winter weather:

“I feel the cold air

On my cheeks and arms and legs

Winter has come”

“A cold winter day

Driving rain and sleet and snow

What is winter like?”

Here’s another poem about winter:

“A dark night in winter

Walking home through the rain

Cold and wet but safe”

Write a story: here are some ideas for writing stories about winter.

You could write a story about someone who lives in a place where it snows all year round. Or you could write a story about a family who is going on a winter vacation. Or you could write a story about a person who has to go outside in the winter to get groceries.

Here’s an example of a winter story:

“I am walking home

From the grocery store

When I see a man

Sitting on the street

Shivering and crying.

I offer him my coat

And some soup from the grocery store.”

In the winter, we get snow, rain, sleet, and ice.

Snow is white, and snowflakes fall from the sky. When you are outside, it is hard to walk on slippery ice because your feet slip and slide around.

Rain makes puddles on the ground, and raindrops hit your face and make you cold.

Sleet is like tiny ice cubes that fall from the sky. They can be dangerous because they can freeze when they hit the ground and make it very slippery.

Winter weather is caused by the Earth spinning around the Sun. When the Earth spins, it moves around the Sun. As the Earth moves, the Sun hits the Earth at a different angle, and this causes the weather to change. It gets colder and colder until it starts getting warmer again.

full_output:
Write a haiku: the sound of leaves
crunching underfoot
follow me home

How did you do it?
I don’t have a big garden. Just the back yard where I let the trees grow wild. In the front I just let the grass go to weeds so the birds can have a place to stay. But they all come to the back yard when we’re feeding the squirrels, chipmunks, deer, and birds.

But I have a pretty good-sized garden area in back. Just in the last couple of years I’ve filled my flower beds and now I’m just waiting for things to start sprouting from seeds I planted late last year.

My son and I planted some sunflowers this year. They’re not real tall but I planted them under the birdfeeder and some of them are right near the fence where the chipmunks come and sit on the ledge and stuff their little cheeks with sunflower seeds, and then sit and eat them.

One year we had a pair of deer visit the yard. We were sitting inside when we heard some rustling outside on the deck. We went out and there was a doe standing on the deck in the shade. She didn’t run away at all. She just stood there staring at us. We went back inside and a few minutes later we went out there again and the fawn was lying on the deck asleep. It was so cute!

Now I’m just waiting to see what else comes by to visit the yard.

Your turn.
Write a poem about the animals in your backyard.

Write a haiku: haiku is a japanese form of poetry written in three lines with a specific 5, 7, 5 pattern to the syllables. Haiku are traditionally based on a single season and present a vivid picture or sensation. The 5-7-5 pattern is often disregarded by modern haiku writers in the west. Haiku by Basho (1644-1694) from my collection of haiku:

Basho (1644-1694) haiku

haiku is not about:

  • feelings
  • emotions
  • thoughts
  • stories
  • poems


  • one season
  • a single moment
  • a vivid picture or sensation

some say:

  • it isn’t poetry if it’s in prose
  • it isn’t poetry if it’s under 17 syllables
  • it isn’t poetry if it’s from another genre

but it is still poetry as it:

  • is written
  • has rhythm and meter
  • is meant to be read

my haiku:

i have not been here
no, not yet, as the sun sets
and the moon rises

my haiku is a:

  • 5 syllable line (2 feet)
  • 7 syllable line (3 feet)
  • 5 syllable line (2 feet)

all the syllables are:

  • short
  • long
  • short

the haiku is about:

  • a moment, but there’s also a sense of what comes next
  • one season, summer and autumn
  • a vivid picture, the sun setting and the moon rising, that could be on any autumn afternoon

modern haiku:

modern haiku is a movement within the Japanese haiku community which started during the 1960s as a revolt against traditional concepts about the genre. The movement advocates abandoning the notions of kireji (kana cutting word) and monomane (imitation of some aspect of nature) in haiku writing. Many traditionalists feel that the movement has moved haiku away from the purity and simplicity that is its essence. Modern haiku practitioners often attempt to write haiku in a way that is very close to how a camera would capture the scene on which it is focused.

  • feelings
  • emotions
  • thoughts
  • stories
  • poems

Write a haiku: there's no reason not to. I love writing haiku. The form is simple (in English it usually has 5 syllables, 7 syllables, and 5 syllables again), you don't have to rhyme or make use of any kind of meter.

My haiku about writing haiku:

Here's the moonlight
reflecting from the still pool
and in my haiku.

My haiku about my friend's cat:

There's a fat cat
sitting in the window
sleeping lazily.

As you can see, you don't have to use proper sentence structure. I like to think of haiku as a kind of writing sketch. You don't need to spend a lot of time on each one. This is the first question you should ask yourself when you're wondering if you're really writing a poem or not. A poem can be a love poem, a haiku about nature, or a free-verse poem that isn't any particular form. In general, it's a short piece of writing with an arrangement of words and sounds that are meant to express an idea or emotion. You usually write in stanzas, or "paragraphs."

But the definition of a poem is very open, so anything can be a poem. A shopping list can be a poem (although it wouldn't be the best poem in the world, unless it really rhymed and was a very, very funny list of items). And a dictionary can be a poem (see "Flarf") if someone writes a poem by looking up each word and using it as the next line.

full_output:
Write a haiku: there's no telling
what you'll get from a haiku!

What is a haiku? Here's one, so it must be a definition:


That's an interesting definition, but not really a "definition". It defines what it's not, and gives an idea of what it is, but it doesn't tell us "what". Perhaps a bit more clarification would be in order.

Wikipedia tells us that Haiku "is a form of unrhymed Japanese poetry" [1]. I disagree with that definition. It might be an attribute of Haiku, but that's not what makes Haiku Haiku. This is the first thing you can notice when you read Haiku - they're short. Not only short, they're short with a strong syllabic structure. Wikipedia goes on: "a poem of three lines, usually with five syllables in the first line, seven in the second and five again in the third".

That's not quite accurate either. The "7-5" definition is popular among Westerners, but not among Japanese. If you're familiar with Japanese you know it's rather difficult to say what syllable the words fall in, as syllables in Japanese aren't usually separated from one another. This is also why the Japanese refer to this "numbering" as "on" [2], which basically means "sound". So you could say that the first sound is at five, the second at seven, etc. This would make "Haiku" into a series of 5/7/5/7/5 "sounds". However, if you read the Wikipedia definition, it mentions "syllables". This can cause a lot of grief when writing Haiku. I'm American, so I don't write in Japanese characters. I use "Latin characters", also known as the "Roman Alphabet" - in English, these are the letters: "a-b-c-d-e-f-g-h-i-j-k-l-m-n-o-p-q-r-s-t-u-v-w-x-y-z" (I'll just call them "letters"). Since Haiku are made of syllables, and syllables are a way to write down words, I can't just start writing words and go 5/7/5/7/5/7/5 (because that's not syllables, it's a series of words). However, I can write, say, 5 "words" and then go on to a second set

The focus of the poem is on a single observation, usually about nature. It presents one scene in a way that focuses on all five senses. A haiku does not rhyme or contain rhyme words.


  • A haiku does not have a specific subject or theme, but it often deals with nature.
  • A haiku does not need to have titles or traditional rhyme. Haikus are generally broken into three lines. The first line contains 5 syllables, the second 7, and the third 5 again.
  • Some examples of a haiku include:
    "The first cold day:
    Ice forms on the pond,
    and a heron fish" - Matsuo Basho
    "Wind in the reeds;
    The fragrance of rice -
    A summer night." - Katsuyori Moori
    "Autumn moonlight -
    A worm comes out of the hole
    in a fallen leaf." - Kichiku Katsuaki
    "The moon rises.
    A thousand mountains appear.
    The cuckoo calls." - Ki no Tsurayuki
    "The night is deep,
    With dew and misty rain:
    How cold are the fields!" - Basho Matsuo
    "A butterfly
    Comes and goes in the dream
    Of the autumn sleep." - Ono no Komachi

Limericks usually have a very simple rhythm in order to make them easy to remember, and this rhythm can be shown in writing by the use of lines which are all the same length. Write a haiku: a white cat sleeping
a white cat sleeping
where's my mouse?

What was that about?

This haiku's about my cat. I found her sleeping today, and took a picture, but I had to wake her up in order to do so, so this is about the moment of her awakening too. I think this picture shows the essence of cat behavior. They are, of course, nocturnal animals, but are sleeping most of the day and, when they're not sleeping, they're usually sleeping... and when I took that picture, she actually started sleeping again (even though she only just had gotten out of bed). She's a cute and cuddly little one, and very friendly, but like all cats she is prone to doze off just when you want to cuddle, and the haiku reflects that.

A cat's life

We could say that a cat's life is a sleep-filled one. But what is life without sleep? It would be impossible to get through it without a good amount of sleep. Sleep is needed to be able to think, work, and live. So cats' life is a life full of sleep, because they are doing everything that is needed for a good life, because they are living. Cats are, however, lazy, at least mine are. I don't mind, though. If you don't know it already, you should: cats are awesome. This is one of the reasons why. They're lazy and they know it.

1 comment:

  1. I'd like to add that there are certain types of cats that tend to be very active and like to play all the time, and some cats, like the ones you have, that like to laze around the house and then suddenly start jumping around and acting like it's the middle of the night when it isn't. :P I would say my cat is the latter type, though we're working on helping him learn how to be less lazy. ^^;

Monday, September 26, 2011

It's Not Fair!

My son came home today, telling me he had to pay a $5 fee, even though it wasn't his fault. It seems that the student who had been in his class from last year, had transferred to a different class and he now had to pay the substitute teacher's fee because it was his name on the substitute's roster, even though the name on the roster wasn't him. He was angry, because it was not his fault. The substitute teacher came to him and asked him for the $5 and he explained to her that he had a different name than the boy in his class, and then he had to tell her who she was looking for. She was okay about it, but my son was livid.

So, I took him to the principal to talk about this "not fair" issue. He was even more angry about the $5 fine, even though I explained that he wouldn't have had to pay it if his name wasn't on the substitute's roster. He kept saying, "I don't have to do anything! It's not my fault!" So, I told him that he needed to learn to accept responsibility for his actions. He had given his classmate his schedule to copy and now he was having to pay the fine, because his name was on the substitute's roster. Was he sorry? Of course! But, he was not the one who had given his name and he didn't think he should have to pay for it.

In our house, there are no but's. If you do something, then you have to own it and take responsibility for it. You can't say something like "I didn't do it, but....." or "I didn't know it was going to happen, but...." It's Not Fair!

My son came home today, telling me he had to pay a $5 fee, even though it wasn't his fault. It seems that the student who had been in his class from last year, had transferred to a different class and he now had to pay the substitute teacher's fee because it was his name on the substitute's roster, even though the name on the roster wasn't him. He was angry, because it was not his fault. The substitute teacher came to him and asked him for the $5 and he explained to her that he had a different name than the boy in his class, and then he had to tell her who she was looking for. She was okay about it, but my son was livid.

So, I took him to the principal to talk about this "not fair" issue. He was even more angry about the $5 fine, even though I explained that he wouldn't have had to pay it if his name wasn't on the substitute's roster. He kept saying, "I don't have to do anything! It's not my fault!" So, I told him that he needed to learn to accept responsibility for his actions. He had given his classmate his schedule to copy and now he was having to pay the fine, because his name was on the substitute's roster. Was he sorry? Of course! But, he was not the one who had given his name and he didn't think he should have to pay for it.

In our house, there are no but's. If you do something, then you have to own it and take responsibility for it. It may not be your fault, but if you had to do something, then you need to take responsibility for it. I think that is the problem today. full_output:
Write a haiku: there is a light
at the end of the tunnel. . . .

A haiku is often given in two lines.
It can be read as two sentences or one.
It does not have to have a title.
It may express a mood or a feeling.

When written as two sentences,
the caesura is implied.
This is the place where the voice is stopped
with a word, phrase, or even a line break.

The caesura is used in English
to create a natural break in the verse.
In Spanish we can use punctuation marks
to break the rhythm of the words.

This is also good to remember
when using the haiku in English.
Haiku is based on syllables,
not the English word.

In this haiku there are eight syllables
in the first line, seven in the second
and five in the third.
This is the traditional form of haiku.

There are no strict rules to follow,
you can try different forms,
and even skip a syllable in the last line,
or try a one sentence haiku.

But the traditional form
is the most popular,
although many people
feel it's too rigid.

They use the syllable form of the haiku
to write poetry that uses similes,
metaphors and other poetic devices.

Others feel the haiku
cannot have a title.
There is a feeling that
it must stand alone.

You might want to try one without a title
just to give it a try.
A haiku is short
and can be read quickly.

There is little time to read
a title and a poem,
and then think about
the haiku form and title.

Sometimes it's nice to read
a haiku just as a short poem.
If you don't like the haiku,
forget it and try another.

Writing a haiku is the easy part.
The difficult part is finding
a title that goes with it.
But it's a fun challenge to do.

There is an old saying that if you have
an interesting topic to write about,
then you'll have no problem writing.
That's true, but sometimes you find
a good topic with a bad haiku.

So try one without a title
just for a change.
I'd like to see what you create.

It may be very good,
or it may be bad,
but we can learn from our mistakes.
That's an important lesson to learn.

Haiku is a way

Lucky 13 and counting. That is how many days this month I have written a poem in the style of the poet and writer, William Carlos Williams. 13 days and counting. I have even managed to write more than one poem some days. That makes me feel very lucky, because I thought I would have trouble finding inspiration from the poet's works. So I'm lucky today that the sun is shining, because today I am finding it much easier to write.

Lucky 13. The number 13 is usually seen as a bad luck number. But for me this month, it is a lucky number. I was lucky to come up with an idea that would help me write every day in the style of WCW. Write a haiku: what are you most
grateful for in your life? A
palm tree? A song? A kiss?

The world is made out of poems

The world is made out of poems, it is
all in how we see it. Like a
flower that is seen as a flower. We can
put it in our minds and look at the
sun shining on it from the left and we can
see the dew forming. Like a poem
that can be read from the left of the flower
to the right. Or we can go inside
the flower, through it’s petals, and see the
stamen and the pistil, the
male and the female. Like a couple
that has been together since they
were young. There are so many ways
of seeing things in the world and
that is what it means that the world is
made out of poems. The way we see
it it a poem.


A poem in itself a universe

I am thinking about what a poem is. And I think it is something that has a very
deep meaning. If I take a line from a poem I know and try to explain the meaning
of it – it might become a long story. The meaning is a universe in itself. If I take
a sentence from the story of A Thousand and One Nights and try to write a poem
out of it, it might become a whole world. I guess this is how poetry works. It is
like a microcosm. You can take something very little, and make it
something big, very meaningful.

Write a haiku: Haikus are simple, poems that describe things in nature. A typical haiku follows a specific form: three lines of 5, 7 and 5 syllables, or beats.

To write a haiku, start by describing something in nature that interests you. Think about where you can place emphasis in the haiku. Maybe you'll want to describe the "sound of the leaves" rather than the "leaves" themselves. This is a great way to use descriptive language and include some metaphors or similes.

Once you have a topic and some descriptive language, put the words into a three line structure. Make sure that the number of syllables and beats are as follows:

1st Line = 5 syllables or beats

2nd Line = 7 syllables or beats

3rd Line = 5 syllables or beats

Example: The sound of the leaves.

They rustle in the wind.

The sound of the leaves, the sound of life.

You'll notice that this example haiku is a bit longer than usual, but it still follows the basic structure.


  • To practice writing haikus, you can read more examples and try writing some on your own.

full_output:
Write a haiku: an act, a moment,
a flash in the pan
An example of how not to write a Haiku:

You can't go on
Forever being a pain
Get off of my brain

Although the original poem is a haiku, the final three lines don't form a haiku because they are five syllables in length. I'll explain more of what makes a haiku later. Right now, though, I want to make sure that you understand the difference between writing the haiku in American form and traditional Japanese haiku form.

American Haiku

American haiku is generally structured as a three line, seventeen syllable poem. This style of haiku was made famous through the work of the Japanese poet, Masaoka Shiki and the American poets Amy Lowell, Paul Carus and Harold J. Gomes who are often referred to as the founders of modern haiku. While some poets still write American haiku in this manner, you'll notice the haiku in this book and in the haiku that we write in this class, are written in a style more closely resembling the way in which haiku are written in Japan.

Japanese Haiku

Unlike its American cousin, Japanese haiku has two distinct features that give it a very distinctive style.

1. The Kigo, or seasonal words.
2. The kireji, or "cutting word" at the end of the first or third line.

The Japanese poet Basho best explained these features in his essay, Haiku's Essence which was written in 1672.

"The point of a poem," he wrote, "is that something has to be put between two things, like an object in the empty space between two windows."

The kigo (seasonal words) is the object and the kireji is the empty space.

This is an example of a Japanese haiku:
Autumn evening--
the crow as before
caws his lonely grief.

There are no commas or full stops to break the poem up, so the haiku is very short and concentrated. When you read this haiku, you may not know what it means, but you get an emotional response because it gives a sense of time, a season, and a sense of a lone, isolated crow.

Here's the problem with the American version of the haiku:

An old silent pond...
A frog jumps into the pond,
splash! Silence again.

There is a strong and definite sense of the season and the environment

2. The kireji, or "cutting word" at the end of the first or third line.

The Japanese poet Basho best explained these features in his essay, Haiku's Essence which was written in 1672.

"The point of a poem," he wrote, "is that something has to be put between two things, like an object in the empty space between two windows."

The kigo (seasonal words) is the object and the kireji is the empty space.

This is an example of a Japanese haiku:
Autumn evening--
the crow as before
caws his lonely grief.

There are no commas or full stops to break the poem up, so the haiku is very short and concentrated. When you read this haiku, you may not know what it means, but you get an emotional response because it gives a sense of time, a season, and a sense of a lone, isolated crow.

Here's the problem with the American version of the haiku:

An old silent pond...
A frog jumps into the pond,
splash! Silence again.

There is a strong and definite sense of the season and the environment

What Is Haiku?

Haiku is a type of Japanese poetry, but it has come to be a style of poetry in English. It is sometimes called nature poetry.

The haiku has a very specific rhythm, structure, and tone. It focuses on a single image or scene that is often set outdoors, in nature. Many haikus are about the seasons.

Haiku is an excellent choice for National Poetry Month because it makes you think carefully about word choice and how to convey a message in as few words as possible.

A haiku must follow the traditional 5-7-5 pattern, meaning that the first and third lines each have 5 syllables, and the second line has 7 syllables.

Let's check out a few examples:

  • Summer sun
  • Hot as the fire in my hearth
  • I long for winter
  • The first line contains 5 syllables, the second has 7, and the third returns to 5 syllables.

  • Rainy day
  • Dripping from trees and leaves
  • A symphony
  • This example features an image of nature, just like many haikus, but it also creates a sense of sound, rhythm, and harmony.

  • Soft, fluffy clouds
  • They're like cotton in the sky
  • Just like the ones
  • Here we have a simile, comparing fluffy clouds to cotton in the sky. It shows how careful word choice is necessary for haiku.

  • Morning sun
  • The grass is sizzling with heat
  • My toes are cold
  • Finally, this example presents an interesting contrast. The morning sun is hot, but the grass is sizzling with heat, which creates a more powerful, visual image. The last line is a great example of a metaphor because it compares a person's toes to cold.

Haiku is a lot of fun because it requires you to think about what you want to say in as few words as possible. This makes it a unique poetic form. Also, don't forget to share your haiku poetry with the family and friends. They are bound to enjoy them.

We hope you are inspired to create your own haiku poems during this year's National Poetry Month.

I write poetry and prose  when I see something or have
a thought or emotion.   Then, I write.   The words flow out like
a river.   It is the best feeling in the world!

Sometimes, I make my poem better.   Sometimes, I throw it away
and start over.  It is like creating a sculpture that I can make real.  
I can make it better by revising.  If I throw it away, my sculpture
is still there.   My thoughts are the same.  Then, I create a new
poem.   Another sculpture.

When people talk about becoming a better version of themselves, they sometimes reference “self-actualization.” Here’s a definition from the dictionary:

“A drive or tendency to improve one’s personal characteristics or capabilities.” (

“Meow meow,” said the Pussycat,
“That sounds lovely to me.”

Let’s write an animal lyric poem with a rhyme.

  1. Pick an animal.
  2. List words that rhyme, for example: grow, flow, know and so.
  3. Start each verse with the animal name, for example, the tiger and then put other words around it, for example:
    • The tiger, the beautiful tiger…
    • The tiger has large sharp teeth
    • The tiger will catch his meat
    • The tiger will eat his meat.
  4. Have fun!

Here are some other rhyming poems. You can download the PDF of the rhyming poems by clicking on the image below:

What is a free verse poem? A free verse poem has no rhymes and usually follows no particular rhythm. They are written in the same way that people speak.

We are going to write a free verse poem using similes. A simile is where two things are compared using the words ‘like’ or ‘as’, for example:

  • You are as brave as a lion.
  • I run like the wind.
  • He sings like a bird.

We are also going to write about the things that we can see out of our window or in our garden. We will use our senses – what we can hear, see, smell, feel, taste – to describe these things and we will compare our subject to something else. For example:

  • It is sunny outside, it is as bright as a lamp.
  • It is cold outside, it is as icy as an ice rink.

when you're still? What does it do
when you go?

What is it made of? Water,

It makes it big, big, so big.

Is it possible? Is it possible for it to disappear? I don't know the answer but I wonder how. I wonder how it would be like in the future without water. In the future I hope that there still is water. I hope I am alive to see it. I hope I am alive to enjoy the water. I hope I am alive to enjoy it. I hope I am alive. I hope I am alive to see it in the future.

Write a haiku: a bird sings

Haikus are amazing, and once you know how to do one you'll be able to write one very easily.

First, choose a good subject. It is always better to write your own poem, rather than trying to copy someone else.

Second, a haiku must always follow a structure. The structure is as follows: (first line) 5 syllables, (second line) 7 syllables, (third line) 5 syllables. A syllable is the length of time that takes to make one spoken sound, such as the number of syllables in the word haiku. A word like haiku only has one syllable, whereas, a word like strawberry has four syllables.

Third, haikus also need to have an important object to describe the scene. These three lines (each line having a different object to describe) should be very closely linked and must be easy to see. This means that each line must describe something very easy to see, or be very close to the viewer.

Let's go back to the three lines of the haiku. The first line has 5 syllables, or the number of beats in the sentence. The second line has 7 syllables, and the third line has five syllables.

In the poem (A bird sings) a bird sings, the words a and sing are just filler words, and can easily be taken out. Therefore, the haiku would then be as follows: (first line) bird sings (second line) bird sings. However, since there is only one word on the second line, it is unnecessary to put this line.

So, what do you think? Let me know what you think of my poem and I'd also love it if you could send me a haiku of your own. If you want to send me one, I'd also be very happy if you could send it to me on facebook.

Write a haiku: You have to get up, put on clothes, and go to school.
You don't want to, but you have no choice.
You have to be at school by nine.
You get out at 3, and you go home to relax.
School is a very important part of life. It teaches you everything you have to know. You have to make the most of it.
You have to be nice to others, and do your work.
Don't talk back, and don't skip class. If you do those things, you won't make it in life.
If you ever feel depressed, or need help, don't be afraid to talk to a teacher, counselor, or other students.
You have to go to school for a while, you might as well make the most of it.

Daddy longlegs

You think they are spiders. You call them daddy longlegs. But they are not spiders at all.
Daddy longlegs are bugs, arachnids to be exact. The ones found in the U.S. are in the order Opiliones.
Daddy longlegs have no venom. That is a myth. They have no fangs. 
Daddy longlegs do not spin webs. They are hunters.
Daddy longlegs have no silk. They are not web builders.
Daddy longlegs are a species of their own.

I like daddy longlegs.
I like their long legs.
Longer than a spider's.

So silly is a funny kind of thing.
So silly is a funny kind of person.
So silly is just silly.
You just have to put up with it.

Your friends?

Your friends' parents?
Your family's friends?

Your neighbors?
Other kids your age?
Strangers? The opposite sex?

Who do you trust?

They scare me.

Use a simile

A simile compares two things with the word 'like' or 'as'. They can describe things or feelings. For example, if something is 'as big as an elephant', it is big. If something is 'as light as a feather', it is light. Can you think of any?

Use a metaphor

A metaphor compares one thing to another thing that it is not literally similar to. It's often a way of describing someone or something with colourful words. Some of the best metaphors come from poets and songs.

For example, 'I saw a face in the crowd and it changed my world' or 'The world is a stage'. Some famous metaphors come from songs or novels. Here's an example from 'The Sun has Got its Hat On' by Terry Southern and Mason Williams:

The cat's in the cradle, the silver spoon

Little boy blue and the man in the moon

The cat's in the cradle and the silver spoon

Little boy blue and the man in the moon

I've got eyes in the back of my head

I've got you on the brain


Use a proverb

A proverb is a proverb. It's like a little saying. It's a short saying and most of them have been around for ages. They are popular sayings. Here are some popular ones:


  • 'Actions speak louder than words.'
  • 'Good things come to those who wait.'
  • 'Haste makes waste.'
  • 'It never rains, but it pours.'

full_output:
Write a haiku: it is
not about the words, but
the emotions of life

A haiku is a Japanese poem containing 3 lines. The first line contains 5 syllables, the second 7, and the third 5. It is also a form of expression, rather than a poem, that is about capturing a single moment in time, a moment where life is in its simplest, and most pure form. You do not want the haiku to contain more than 17 syllables because you want the reader to be able to say it in 1 breath. It is a part of the genre Haibun, which is a form that combines prose with haiku to express an idea.

Poetry Writing Lesson Plan 4: Creative Poem

You are now ready to compose your own creative poem. Remember that a poem can be any length, but keep it under 16 lines. The first thing you need is an idea. It is best if this idea relates to your other writing or interests. The creative poem is not about following any rules; it is about being as free to express yourself as you want. Feel free to use your writing skills you have been learning about writing creative prose to write your poem in a similar style. You should be using descriptive language, and even metaphors and similes to help the reader visualize your poem. Feel free to add rhymes and rhythms, if you feel it will add to the poem and make it sound better. Remember to use good grammar, capitalization and punctuation. It is also best to leave the poem for a few hours, and then return to it. When we write, we often notice mistakes that we did not notice when we were writing. If you give the poem a day to rest, you will have a greater chance of being able to make the corrections it needs.

full_output:
Write a haiku: 6 syllables in line 1, 7 in line 2, 5 in line 3
5 syllables
7 syllables
5 syllables
A little bit of rhyme will help it sound better
The third and last line is the punchline, a great ending to your haiku
The ending will help readers see the connection to your story

Once you’ve written a haiku, read it out loud. Does it sound good? Can you say it again? Now that you’ve read it out loud, does it make sense? Would your haiku make sense to someone else who might not know your family history story? Is it written well enough that other people will understand? Is your haiku just three lines that you really love and that have a family history connection, or do you really think that it is a great haiku?

Next, read your haiku to a family member or a friend. How did your haiku sound to them? Do they understand the haiku?

Finally, it is a good idea to get other opinions. Show several different versions of your haiku to friends and family. Ask them which version of your haiku do they like the best. Why do they like that version? Is it their favorite because the haiku includes important people or an important event that they know about? Once you have heard other people’s comments, you can think about how you want to rewrite your haiku.

One really important way to tell if you’ve written a good haiku is by reading it to your grandfather and asking him if he likes your haiku.

Did you write a haiku about your family history that your grandfather would enjoy? What did your grandfather say?

You might even consider sharing this family history haiku writing experience with your grandfather. What if you wrote a haiku about your family history and you shared it with your grandfather and then he wrote a haiku for you. Now that would be a wonderful way to help your grandfather to record a family history story.

Write a haiku: Haiku are an ancient form of Japanese poetry, composed of three lines with five, seven, and five syllables. They describe a simple moment in nature with just a few words. This activity can help children build their language skills and become better writers. Here's an example:

Springtime arrives
Cherry blossoms float down from trees
A rainbow appears

7. Write a limerick: A limerick is a type of poem that has five lines. The first, second, and fifth lines rhyme, while the third and fourth lines rhyme with each other. The rhyme scheme is AABBA. Limericks are often silly or funny poems. Here's an example:

There once was a bear named Mike
Who lived in a cave near the lake.
He liked fishing so much
That he caught many trout
But he couldn't cook them, so he ate them raw.

8. Write a poem using rhymes and repetition: Rhyming and repetition can make poems more fun and memorable. Encourage children to repeat words or phrases throughout the poem to create a song-like quality. Here's an example:

The snow falls softly outside my window
Making snow angels and snowmen so white and round.
I like playing in the snow,
But sometimes I wish for springtime when flowers bloom.
I dream of being outside on a beautiful day
Running through the grass with my dog by my side.
But for now, I'll stay inside
Until winter passes and springtime arrives.

As you can see, there are many ways to write poems beyond the traditional five lines of rhyming couplets. By encouraging children to explore different forms of poetry, you can help them develop their creativity and language skills in a fun and engaging way. Whether they write haikus or limericks, they will learn valuable writing techniques that will benefit them throughout their academic careers. So grab some paper and start writing!

Write a haiku: a poem in three short phrases; the 1st line has five syllables, the 2nd line has seven, and the 3rd line has five. The three lines of the haiku should all relate to one another. You may use a title, but often the title is not a part of the poem. Examples of haiku: "Lone flower / A solitary blossom / In the moonlight" and "Autumn sunset / The wind stirs up / A golden sea."
  • Sestina (say-steen-uh): a sestina has six stanzas and a final three-line stanza known as an "envoi." The end words of lines 1-4 are repeated in sequence at the end of lines 5-8, and lines 6-9, and lines 2-4, 5-8, and 1-6 of the poem also repeat. The envoi has end words of 5-8-6. Examples of sestina: "The House on the Hill" by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, and "Sestina" by Elizabeth Bishop.
  • Sonnet (sah-noh): an English sonnet is written in iambic pentameter (five  iambs per line) and has three four-line stanzas and a couplet (a two-line stanza). The rhyme scheme is abab cdcd efef gg. An Italian sonnet has two sections; the first is of eight lines in which the rhyme scheme is abbaabba, and the second is a sestet with various rhyme schemes, such as cdecde, cdccdc, or cdccdc. Examples of sonnet: "Sonnet 18" by Shakespeare, and "On His Blindness" by John Milton.
  • Free verse: a poem in which no line in the poem must rhyme with any other line, and no line has a regular meter. Examples of free verse include "Poem" by William Carlos Williams and "The Red Wheelbarrow" by William Carlos Williams.

Free verse, which is the dominant form of poetry in the English language today, is also the easiest one for a new writer to master, because the rules are looser. Write a haiku: the moon
is a glowing white disk
in the midnight sky

by Michael

How to do write a haiku


The Haiku is a Japanese form of poetry that is composed of seventeen syllables and is often about nature or the seasons. If you are interested in writing haiku, try writing it with a certain word limit. For example, five syllables on the first line, seven syllables on the second line, and five syllables on the third line.

Here are some examples of the three different types of Haiku:


Winter wind blows
Snowflakes drift from the sky
Shadows darken trees

By Lillian

Soft, wet grass
Rain falls gently from the sky
Flowers bloom, birds sing

By Alex


I love this day, spring
Birds are singing all around
And flowers are here

By Miki

You can also use a Haiku to describe things in life, too. For example, here is the Haiku that I wrote for myself.

Haiku about school


A place where I learn
With friends I love to see
And teachers to help

By Michael

Another type of haiku is the senryu. A senryu is like a haiku, but it's about human nature and life. Some examples are:

The student's homework
His mom's loud voice
He's off to work


At the fair today
People laughing at silly things
We're all having fun

Now, if you want, you can make a haiku or a senryu about a certain topic. I'll show you how. Let's try it with sports!

How to Write a Sports Haiku

Sports haiku is fun! It’s easy to write them, too.

We’re going to do an activity where we all make haiku that describe different sports or games. Are you ready? Let’s go!

Here’s how we will do it:

1. First, you will get a piece of paper and draw a picture of a certain sport or game. (You can use any color markers or crayons that you want.)

2. Next, you will write a sentence about your picture and then a haiku poem using the sentence as the subject.

3. When you finish your haiku, you will come back to the group and read your haiku out loud.

4. After we have heard all of the haiku poems, we will vote on which haiku was the best

Write a haiku: 

I think this is a good idea, so I'll try to write 3 haikus right now.
The problem with writing a haiku on a topic that is too broad is that you might end up just describing something very superficially, and it won't say enough to convey what's special about it. It also might be difficult to find an image that fits the syllable count of 5-7-5. Instead, if you focus on a single aspect of a larger subject, you can express a lot more. For example, when writing about a waterfall, you could focus on the power of the falling water, the noise it makes, its rainbow, or the beautiful curves of the water at the base of the waterfall. You might choose a single aspect for each of the 3 haiku that you want to write.
Here are my 3 haiku:
The water falls
With a thunderous roar that echoes
Through the green forest.
When I read this haiku, I immediately visualize a waterfall. The word “thunderous” in the second line reminds me of both the sound of the waterfall and the shape of the falling water. The word “echoes” in the third line reminds me of the way the sound of the waterfall seems to bounce off of everything in the forest, filling it with the sound.
Water that’s crystal clear,

What’s the value of a haiku?

The only thing you can do is write for yourself, so this is something I have to do.


Why do you keep writing?


I am not sure about why I write haiku. I have a feeling that I have the haiku genes in me, I mean you have to be a certain type of person to write a haiku and I think I have the right type of person.


Can you describe your life?

It’s been quite a journey.
I’ve had good days and bad days. I started a new career in January.

As for my health, my symptoms have become severe.

I am going to try and be more optimistic about things.
I have been on a medication, but that wasn’t good and I had to change medication.

Now I will try and be more optimistic and say that good things will come to pass. I am hoping that this medication is going to help and it might give me a break from pain.

I was diagnosed with depression and anxiety for the last five years, so now I’m looking at finding a way to deal with that.

Write a haiku: a red apple

It's a red, ripe apple

A red apple is round and has a good taste to it.  Red apples make good desserts or snacks, and are very tasty as you might notice.  A red apple is the first apple that comes to mind, and red apple is something people like a lot.  A red apple is sweet, round, shiny, ripe, juicy and delicious, a perfect fruit to eat, and this makes it good and makes it be the haiku I choose to write here.
How does the haiku make you feel about the apple?

It makes me want to eat it


How does the poem make you feel about the apple?

It makes you want to eat it


What kind of picture does it paint of an apple in your head?

A ripe, round, red apple that you would like to eat.  An apple that is the first apple that comes to mind, and is something people like a lot.  An apple that is sweet, round, shiny, ripe, juicy and delicious, a perfect fruit to eat.


What kind of apples can you buy at the supermarket?

Red apples, golden delicious, granny smith


How would you describe the apples on an apple tree?

Round, bright red apples


What do you call the stem of an apple?

Stem, leaf, tree


Do you prefer apples cooked or raw?

I love a juicy ripe apple with the stem still attached.  I like it when it's warm from the sun.  I love biting into it and then chewing it.  I like to bite off the stem and have it hanging from my mouth as I chew it.  I can bite the core off and spit it out then I continue eating it.  It makes a great dessert and can be a healthy snack.


Who is the apple for?

The apple is for me!


What do people eat with their apple?

People eat their apple with a knife and fork.  People like to eat their apple in a fruit salad.  People like to have the core removed from their apple.  People eat apples with a little peanut butter on them.  People eat their apple with chocolate on them.  People eat their apple as a desert.  People eat their apple with whipped cream on it.  People eat their apple with caramel on it.  People eat their apple as a snack between meals.


What do you do after eating your apple?

I throw my apple peel away and rinse out

Write a haiku: in honor of our new president, you have to write a haiku about his hair and why it looks the way it does.  He is the first black president, and I don't want to make fun of him for this.  I'd just like to know why he has so much hair on his arms and not on his head.  It looks like he got a mohawk cut and stuck a comb to his head, and the hair from the bottom of his head stuck to the comb and went up on top.  I mean, if I were the head stylist for the president, that's what I would do.  So write your haiku about the president's hair.

I know, for me at least, writing poetry has always been a very cathartic experience.  There were times in my life where I had no one to talk to, and no one to relate to, so I just wrote out all my feelings into a piece of poetry.  I used to write a lot of what people referred to as "angry young man" poetry, and most of it is probably pretty crass.  But sometimes I would write something that I liked, and it was pretty deep and profound.  A lot of it is about how you have to find that special someone that you can trust, and you have to share your life with.  A lot of my poetry is about how I'm too selfish to share my life with someone, and that it's always going to be just me and my dog.  So I encourage you to write some poetry, and don't worry what anyone else thinks.  Your haiku can be silly, or you can write your feelings out, but it can be very therapeutic to get all your feelings out into a poem, and maybe even put some pictures to your poem by drawing a picture or making a collage.
